subject: Travel
title: Chopstick Etiquette in Asia
description: A micro-lesson that makes Chopstick Etiquette in Asia usable.

hook.text: Sticking chopsticks upright in rice is one of the most offensive things you can do in Japan.

buildup.text: It resembles incense at a funeral. To a Japanese host, you've just turned dinner into a death ritual.

discovery.text: In China, pointing with chopsticks is like pointing a finger ‚Äî rude and confrontational.

twist.text: In Korea, metal chopsticks are standard. They started because royals used silver to detect poison.

climax.text: Passing food chopstick-to-chopstick mirrors a Japanese funeral custom. Guests will freeze in horror.

punchline.text: Two sticks. Endless ways to accidentally cause offense.

quiz.question: Why are chopsticks never stuck upright in rice in Japan?
